author: Matthew Smith
title: Perpetual Investments sees value in ASX, deploys 'significant capital'
text:
Perpetual CEO Geoff Lloyd said: "As an active value manager, this is a market where we come into our own." Sasha Woolley by Matthew Smith Active funds manager Perpetual Investments has deployed "significant capital" into the markets in recent weeks, according to chief executive Geoff Lloyd.
The Australian equities focused investment firm, with $30.2 billion of funds under management, was sitting on up to 9 per cent of cash on average in its funds up until the last month, Mr Lloyd said, following the announcement of the firm's full-year financial results on Thursday.
The company announced a 50 per cent increase in full-year net profits to $122.5 million. It said full-year revenue rose 13 per cent to $495.13 million and announced it will pay a final $1.25 dividend on September 25.
In recent weeks, the firm's portfolio managers have put a "significant amount" of capital back into the market, which it had been holding in cash for defensive reasons for the last 12 months, Mr Lloyd said.
He said Perpetual's portfolio managers had begun to find value in the Australian sharemarket in recent weeks on the back of the sell of which saw 14 per cent of the value of the S&P/ASX 200 index wiped off from the end of July to the start of this week when the market index bounced back from its slide.
Volatility in the Australian share market has increased as further concerns about China have materialised and share markets in the in the United States have experienced a sell-off.
"As an active value manager, this is a market where we come into our own," Mr Lloyd said following the firm's results announcement which was greeted favourably by investors. Perpetual's share price was up 5 per cent in late trading on Thursday.
Mr Lloyd said the deployment of capital into the equities market was highlighted by Perpetual Equity Investment Company (PIC), the listed investment company the firm floated on the ASX in December last year.
After raising $250 million PIC held around 60 per cent in cash while the Perpetual's investment team considered the market expensive or fully priced. Lloyd said PIC had invested a substantial amount of that cash in Australian listed companies.
